IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 9859 S1381-1169(16)30146-7 10.1016/j.molcata.2016.04.015 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 (A) The diffractograms of parent zirconia materials, undoped and doped with Al, Si, Fe ions (calcined at 700°C for 3h in an air stream, i.e., ZrO2 phases); and (B) These diffractograms in detail, in the range 27–33.4°. The tetragonal (∼30.3°) and monoclinic (∼28.2°, 31.5°) reflections used for phase evaluation are indicated here. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (A) Illustrative examples of the NH3-TPD curves of parent ZrO2, together with 1.0-mol.%-Si-doped ZrO2, and 1.0-Si-doped-ZrO2 after impregnation with 18 wt.% WO3 (together with mathematical fit curves). (B) The H2-TPR curves of undoped 18%-WO3-ZrO2 and the corresponding Al-doped-18%-WO3-ZrO2 and Al-doped-ZrO2 samples, containing 10 mol.% of Al (+ their mathematical fit curves; dashed lines). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (A) Normalized UV–vis spectra (of WOx bands, in 21,000–47,500cm−1 range) of 5%-Al-doped (a), and 10%-Al-doped (b) 18%-WO3-ZrO2 samples. (B) The corresponding spectra of 0.5%-Si-doped (a) and 1.0%-Si-doped (b) 18%-WO3-ZrO2 samples. (C) The corresponding spectra of 0.5%-Fe-doped (a) and 1.0%-Fe-doped (b) 18%-WO3-ZrO2 samples (WOx species). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 2 Types of deactivation of catalysts: The C7-isomers obtained at reaction temperature 250°C as a function of (a) time-of-stream during continuous feeding and (b) number of interruptions and subsequent reactivations (on Pt/5%-Al-WO3-ZrO2). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 The C7-isomerization activity of doped samples and analogous undoped-WO3-ZrO2. The activity is represented by the yield of iso-C7. A description of the dopant type and its concentration is given along the horizontal axis of the figure. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Dependence of isomerization activity, represented as the yield of iso-C7, on the surface coverage by WOx species. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Dependence of isomerization activity, expressed as the yield of iso-C7, on the overall surface acidity of the resulting WO3-ZrO2 materials. Fig. 7 Table 1 The N2-BET surface area of undoped and dopant-modified ZrO2 samples (calcined at 700°C) and their crystal phases. Table 1 Dopant Modification WO3 (wt.%) Monoclinic/Tetragonal Phases Surface Area (m2/g) 700°C Pure zirconia 0 0.93/0.07 14.8 Pure zirconia 18 0.10/0.90 63.3 5mol% Al 18 0.37/0.63 38.0 10mol% Al 18 0.16/0.84 44.0 0.5mol% Si 18 0.18/0.82 54.4 1.0mol% Si 18 0.13/0.87 51.3 0.5mol% Fe 18 0.90/0.10 28.0 1.0mol% Fe 18 0.90/0.10 41.0 Table 2 The total acidity and the concentrations of strong, medium and weak acid sites in individual samples. [33]. Impact of dopant metal ions in the framework of parent zirconia on the n-heptane isomerization activity of the Pt/WO3-ZrO2 catalysts D. Kaucký a ⁎ Z. Sobalík a J.M. Hidalgo b R. Černý b O. Bortnovský c a J. Heyrovský Institute of Physical Chemistry, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic, v.v.i., Dolejškova 2155/3, CZ-182 23 Prague, Czech Republic J. Heyrovský Institute of Physical Chemistry Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic v.v.i., Dolejškova 2155/3 Prague CZ-182 23 Czech Republic b Research Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, Department of Efficient Refining Technologies (UniCRE-EFFRET), Chempark Litvínov, CZ-43670 Litvínov, Czech Republic Research Institute of Inorganic Chemistry Department of Efficient Refining Technologies (UniCRE-EFFRET) Chempark Litvínov Litvínov CZ-43670 Czech Republic c Eurosupport Manufacturing Czechia Ltd., Chempark Litvínov, CZ-43670 Litvínov, Czech Republic Eurosupport Manufacturing Czechia Ltd. Chempark Litvínov Litvínov CZ-43670 Czech Republic ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Selected Pt/WO3-ZrO2 catalysts, promoted by Al, Si and Fe metal ions and isomorphously substituted into the zirconia framework, were studied and compared with their undoped equivalents as catalysts for C7 isomerization. They were characterized by XRD, UV–vis and TPD-TPR techniques. A mechanism was proposed for the positive dopant effect on the catalyst activity. Keywords Zirconia Tungstated zirconia Dopants Pt/WO3-ZrO2 Heptane isomerization 1 Introduction Zirconia-based materials represent a promising and intensively studied subject because of their specific electronic structure and acidic properties [1–6]. They have broad applications ranging from high-temperature ceramics [7] to sensor technology [8]. Doped zirconia has been successfully used as a solid electrolyte in fuel-cells [9], as a modern luminescent material [10], and/or as a thin-layer substrate in semiconductor devices [11,12]. Heterogeneous catalysis is an important area of application for zirconia-based materials. Since Hino and Arata [13,14] discovered WO3-ZrO2 as a strongly acidic material that isomerizes n-paraffins, a large amount of research has been devoted to the analysis of this solid material. Classical preparation routes typically start from amorphous Zr(OH)4, which is further impregnated with tungstate or other metal precursors, and finally calcined at high temperatures (700–800°C). This results in the formation of strongly acidic materials [15,16] with varying crystallinity and various types of WOx species, depending on the calcination conditions. Platinum is usually introduced during the final stage of the catalyst preparation. Pt is generally thought to play a role in the dissociation of molecular hydrogen present in the feed and/or in the hydrogenation of olefinic intermediates. A large number of studies have been devoted to the analysis of changes in the zirconia surface during the above high-temperature calcination step. During high-temperature calcination, the surface area decreases as individual crystal phases are formed, in both monoclinic and tetragonal zirconia structures. There have been numerous studies on the use of metal ions and/or other modifiers in the zirconia framework, and the effect of such modifiers is mostly associated with surface stabilization [17]. Several examples have been reported, of the modification of WO3-ZrO2 catalyst in different stages of its preparation, by doping with various metals and/or metal ions, e.g., Al [18–20], Fe [21], Mn [22], Ga, In [23] or Cr ions, and/or a combination thereof [24–30]. This work was performed to study the influence of addition of dopant ions on the properties of the Pt/WO3-ZrO2 catalyst used for isomerization of n-heptane. This study focuses on the impact of the dopant on the structure of zirconia, i.e., on the formation of individual crystal phases and their surface properties, including surface area, acidity and formation of WOx species during calcination of the material. Further, an attempt is made to elucidate the relationships among these characteristics and their relevance for the catalytic activity in n-heptane isomerization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials preparation The pure, undoped parent Zr(OH)4 was prepared by precipitation of a ZrOCl2·8H2O solution by ammonia as follows: the aqueous ZrOCl2·8H2O solution (4.5g ZrOCl2·8H2O in 50ml H2O) was precipitated by direct drop-wise addition of concentrated ammonia to pH ∼ 10 under vigorous stirring. The product was then filtered, washed and dried at 105°C. A similar procedure was used for the preparation of metal-doped hydrous zirconium hydroxides Me/Zr(OH)4; an aqueous ZrOCl2·8H2O solution containing the appropriate amount of dopant metal ions was precipitated by drop-wise addition of concentrated ammonia up to pH ∼ 10. Thus, e.g., 0.25g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O was added to the initial ZrOCl2·8H2O solution for preparation of 5%-Al-doped-ZrO2; or 0.1g of ∼36wt.% solution of NaSiO3/H2O was used for preparation of 0.5%-Si-doped-ZrO2; while 30.6mg of Fe2(SO4)3·5H2O was used for preparation of 0.5%-Fe-doped-ZrO2. All other conditions and procedures were similar to those described above for the preparation of pure Zr(OH)4 samples. The WO3-ZrO2 materials were prepared by impregnation of the obtained Zr(OH)4 samples with the required amount of aqueous solution of (NH4)6H2W12O40 (Fluka) to achieve 18wt.% WO3 in the final WO3-ZrO2 (calculated with respect to the initial parent material, regardless of the dopant concentration and/or mass loss during the calcinations). The products were separated by filtration, washed and dried overnight at 105°C, and finally calcined in a flow of dry air (heating rate 0.7°Cmin−1) at a temperature of 700°C for 3h. Pt was introduced into the calcined solids prior to the catalytic reaction, via impregnation by a H2PtCl6 solution to yield 1.0wt.% of Pt in the target material. 2.2 Materials characterizations XRD diffractograms of the prepared solids were recorded on an Xcalibur PX enhanced diffractometer (Oxford Diffraction, U.K.) using CuKα radiation with wavelength 1.54Å in the 2θ range 4–70° with a step of 0.0167°. The results were evaluated using XPERT-PRO instrument software. The BET specific surface area was determined from the N2 adsorption isotherms measured at 77K (at liquid N2 temperature) on an ASAP 2010 apparatus (Micromeretics, U.S.A.). Temperature-programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2-TPR) was performed on an AMI-200 apparatus (Altamira Instruments, Inc., U.S.A.). The samples (typically 100mg) were first treated in a U-shaped quartz reactor in a stream of synthetic air at 450°C for 3h and then cooled to room temperature. The H2-TPR experiment was then performed in the same reactor in a mixture of hydrogen (9.44vol.%) in argon, at a flow rate of 30cm3 min−1 and with a temperature increase of 10°Cmin−1. TCD was used as a detector of H2-consumption. The quantitative analysis was performed using peak areas, where calibration was performed by the H2 pulse technique with 5 pulses. The acidity of the prepared solids was monitored by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) using the same apparatus (AMI-200, Altamira Instruments, Inc., U.S.A.). The samples (again typically 100mg) were first pre-treated in hydrogen at 250°C for 1h, followed by ammonia adsorption at 100°C from a stream of 3.95 vol.% ammonia in helium. The ammonia desorption was then carried out in a flow of helium with a temperature increase of 20°Cmin−1, with the same detection and quantity analysis as described above. Diffuse-Reflectance UV–vis spectra of samples were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 950 spectrometer, equipped with a diffuse-reflectance sphere attachment with a Spectralon coated integrating sphere. Owing to the high absorption of the measured undoped and doped WO3–ZrO2 samples (above Schuster–Kubelka–Munk (SKM) function >3), which does not allow quantitative analysis of the spectra, the samples were diluted with BaSO4. Diffuse-reflectance spectra were then recorded in a differential mode using a mixture of BaSO4/ZrO2 (ratio 5:1) as a reference. The WO3–ZrO2 samples were diluted with BaSO4 up to an amount where they exhibited BaSO4/ZrO2 ratio identical to that of the reference mixture. This arrangement compensated for the strong absorption band of ZrO2 at 43,500cm−1 in the recorded spectra and established conditions for reliable analysis of the band intensities of the tungstate species. The UV–vis spectra were recorded in the range 2500–200nm at a speed of 240nm.min−1 with a scanning step of 1nm and slit width of 5nm. The absorption intensity was calculated employing the Schuster–Kubelka–Munk equation, F(R∞)=(1−R∞)2/2.R∞, where R∞ is the diffuse reflectance from a semi-infinite layer and F(R∞) is proportional to the absorption coefficient. Data processing was carried out using Microcal Origin 7.5 (Microcal Software, Inc., USA). 2.3 Isomerization reaction conditions and evaluation of results The isomerization of n-heptane to the corresponding iso-heptanes was carried out in a glass flow-through U-shaped reactor, typically with 0.50g of the catalyst placed on a porous glass bed. The catalyst (in the form of 0.25-0.5mm pellets) was activated before the reaction in a stream of oxygen at 475°C for 3h, then briefly (15min) purged by a N2 stream at 475°C, then cooled down to 250°C in a N2 stream and finally activated in a mixture of 80 mol% H2 +20 mol% N2 at 250°C for 1h. Then, the stream containing 79 mol% H2, 20 mol% N2 and 1mol% of paraffin was directly fed with a flow rate of 66cm3.min−1, which corresponded to WSHV 0.35h−1. n-Heptane was fed using a conventional saturator kept at the required temperature. The temperature of the reactor was kept at a desired the temperature in the range 200–300°C. The outlet of n-heptane, iso-heptanes and low-molecular weight products (mostly propane and butane; aromatics were not found among the products) was analysed by an on-line connected Finnigan 9001 gas chromatograph equipped with a 50m×0.32mm×5μm Al2O3/KCl capillary column and a TCD detector. Steady-state conditions were achieved within 0.5–3h of the reaction time-on-stream. The conversion, selectivity and yields of the isomerization reaction were defined as: conversion x(%)=(C0,n-heptane−Cn-heptane)/C0,n-heptane ×102 selectivity s(%)=Ciso-heptanes/(C0,n-heptane−Cn-heptane)×102 yield η(%) =Ciso-heptane/C0,n-heptane ×102 where: C0,n-heptane is the concentration of n-heptane in the reactor inlet, Cn-heptane and Ciso-heptanes are the concentrations (inmol.%) of n-heptane and iso-heptanes, respectively, in the products. 3 Results 3.1 Structural properties of undoped vs. metal-ion-doped catalysts XRD showed the influence of dopant ions on the formation of zirconia crystal phases [31] and the shift of their diffraction patterns, especially with Al as a dopant. This reflects isomorphous substitution into the framework (Fig. 1 ). The dopant incorporation causes a preference for the tetragonal crystal phase over the monoclinic phase in all of the doped samples compared with the undoped material, and the diffraction pattern of this tetragonal phase at 30.15° is shifted to approx. 30.42°. The largest shift was observed for the sample doped with 10% Al. The effects are better illustrated in Fig. 1B, which shows a detailed view of the previous Fig. 1A, in the 27–33° range. All of the shifts in the diffraction patterns observed after dopant were introduced as well as the absence of any diffraction patterns of newly appearing phases (such as the absence of alumina in Al-doping) indicate the isomorphous substitution of dopants into the framework of the zirconia supports. 3.2 Surface area of undoped vs. metal-ion-doped catalysts The surface area of the samples was determined from N2-BET isotherms collected at liquid nitrogen temperature. These values, together with the ratios of crystal phases are given in Table 1 . After precipitation and drying, the fresh zirconia hydroxides had a surface area ranging between 140 and 190m2/g, (not shown in Table 1). The calcination of these materials led to a substantial decrease in the surface area (15–63m2/g), and the resulting values were strongly dependent on the type and level of dopant metal ion, see the values in the last column of Table 1. 3.3 TPD study of the doped samples The TPD-NH3 results indicate the presence of acid sites of three different acid strengths in all zirconia-containing samples: acid sites of low strength (NH3 desorption <250°C); those of medium acid strength (desorption peak at approximately 400°C), and strongly acidic centres with desorption temperatures over 525°C. (The individual bands are indicated in Fig. 2 A by mathematical fit curves.) Metal-doping had the effect of slightly suppressing all acid sites (see Fig. 2A) in pure zirconia. Further impregnation of these doped-ZrO2 samples with tungsten (Fig. 2A) accelerated the appearance of both medium-strength and weakly acidic sites, while the concentration of strong acid sites remained low. Fig. 2A shows the effect of Si-dopant on ZrO2 acidity. The changes in the TPD curves document a slight decrease in all types of acid sites in Si-doped-ZrO2, compared to the parent material. After impregnation of the Si-doped sample by 18% WO3, the medium sites (desorption ∼400°C) as well as the weak acid sites (desorption ∼250°C) strongly increased, while the strong acid sites (desorption >525°C) were apparently decreased in comparison with the parent zirconia and Al-doped parent materials. Sites of both medium and weak acidity steadily increased with increasing Si-dopant concentration. The impact of dopant incorporation on the total concentration of acid sites, compared with pure zirconia or Si-doped zirconia and W-impregnated zirconia without Si-dopant, is given in Table 2 . Very similar trends for acidity changes were observed using Fe as dopants, while Al-dopants had a slight opposite effect. Acidity characteristics for all samples are summarized in Table 2. 3.4 TPR study of doped samples The effect of Al, Si, and Fe dopants on the reducibility of the formed WOx species supported on the zirconia was studied. In general, the reduction patterns could be separated into four individual reduction peaks at temperatures of 450°C, 600°C, 700°C and 800°C. The effect of doping is exemplified in Fig. 2B for the Al-doped samples, and evaluation of the individual TPR bands of all studied materials is summarized in Table 3 . The parent metal-doped-ZrO2 samples also exhibited H2-consumption (0.2–0.5mmol/g), although the parent undoped-ZrO2 did not (<0.1mmol/g). The small values of this doped-ZrO2 parent consumption were subtracted from the measured values for the corresponding WO3-impregnated doped ZrO2 samples, and only the resultant values are presented in Table 3. TPR revealed that metal-doping decreased the total consumption of H2 over all Me-doped-WO3-ZrO2 samples. The reducibility of the parent Me-doped-ZrO2 could be attributed to the formation of specific crystallographic defects, such as oxygen vacancies, the formation of which might be facilitated by the presence of dopant in the ZrO2 framework [19]. Assuming additivity of the hydrogen consumptions by the ZrO2 support and the WOx surface species, the H2-consumption for WOx demonstrated a H2/WOx ratio of 2.3-2.9. 3.5 UV–vis spectroscopy of doped samples To separately identify the UV–vis spectra of WOx, the spectra were recorded in two different regimes: a regime enabling separation of WOx bands for undoped and doped samples (no Al- or Si-bands were detectable), and a regime used for separation of the WOx bands for Fe-doped parent as well as separation of Fe-bands (as specified in the Experimental Part). The obtained spectra are presented in Fig. 3A–C . The spectra yielded relative populations of the individual bands representing mono- and poly-nuclear WOx species, and bulk-like WOx species [32], as well as their dependence on the type and concentration of dopant. It is clearly seen that all dopants affected the concentration of the individual WOx species. However, the effect was smaller for the Al-dopants and greatest for the Fe-dopants. From the observed changes in the shapes of the individual bands, it is possible that the character of the corresponding species was also changed. Additionally, in the sample doped by iron, Fe-bands were detected at 29,000, (33,000), 38,000 and (44,000)cm−1. The populations of the individual WOx species; mono-nuclear, poly-nuclear and bulk-like [32], were further influenced by the type and concentration of metal-dopant ions in the framework of the ZrO2 support. The influence of Al-dopant ions was negligible, and Si-dopant ions slightly increased the formation of poly-nuclear WOx species. However, in presence of Fe-dopant ions, the concentration of the bulk WOx species increased strongly. 3.6 Isomerization activity Generally, all of the catalysts studied here suffered from some deactivation in two ways, as evidenced by the decrease in isomerization activity (to some extent) as the reaction proceeded. To illustrate this point, the dependence of isomer yield on reaction progress is shown in Fig. 4 . Therefore, all of the values presented here were collected in a continuous regime after a steady state was reached. The catalytic performances of the dopant-modified Pt/WO3-ZrO2 catalysts for the isomerization of n-heptane and its comparison with the performance of the undoped Pt/WO3-ZrO2 at a temperature of 250°C are given in Table 4 . The catalytic data given in this Table represent steady-state values reached with time-on-stream. The iso-C7 yields are reported together with the selectivity and yield of low-molecular products, which consisted mainly of C1-C4 hydrocarbons, i.e., methane-to-butane (and iso-butane in some cases). The respective values of iso-C7 yields for the individual samples are compared in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5 shows that doping of Pt/WO3-ZrO2 with Al, Si or Fe-dopants resulted in increased activity at a reaction temperature of 250°C and/or at higher temperatures. In addition, the formation of undesirable low-molecular products was suppressed by the doped catalysts. The optimal concentration for improved catalytic activity differed for each individual dopant, but the positive effects decreased uniformly if this optimal concentration was exceeded. Thus, the optimal loading was found to be: ∼5mol% for Al- and 0.5mol% for Si- and Fe-dopant (see Table 4 and Fig. 5). From previous experience (obtained during industrial collaboration, not reported here) it was obvious that the range of dopant loading should be tested within specified limits (i.e., should begin at cca 5mol% for Al-dopant and cca 10x lower for Si and Fe-dopants). Based on the results of XRD and other structure-characterization techniques, it appears that the dopant metal ions were introduced into the framework of the parent zirconia. However, it was not clear whether the effects on the isomerization activity could be achieved solely by this framework-dopant and/or whether the dopant needed to be introduced on the surface of the support. To clarify the importance of the location of the dopants, the Al-dopant was also introduced by post-zirconia-synthesis impregnation (i.e., practically onto the surface), otherwise prepared in the same way. The activity was compared with the framework dopant-modified catalyst, described here. To verify these two types of dopant introduction, both types of Al-dopant-modified samples were monitored by XPS and 27Al-NMR, and the difference between them thus confirmed. The isomerization activity in the temperature range 200–300°C indicated a positive effect when framework Al-dopant was introduced, while a negative effect resulted for surface Al-dopant. 4 Discussion The principal question targeted by this study was the possible role of the dopant ion in the parent zirconia used for subsequent impregnation by WO3, and how the properties of the doped zirconia-support affect the activity of the resulting catalyst for paraffin isomerization. For this purpose, zirconia doped with Al, Si, and Fe dopant ions was used for preparation of WO3-ZrO2 catalyst. The doping elements were introduced during co-precipitation of the parent zirconia hydroxide; and the dopant concentration ranged between 5–10mol% for Al-dopant, and between 0.5–1.0mol% for Si and Fe dopants. Because the same amount of WO3 precursor was subsequently used during WO3-ZrO2 impregnation and because the same value of 18wt.% of WO3 was targeted in the final material, the doped supports differed in surface area and many other parameters. As a result, catalysts with surface coverage varying between 6.10 and 13.70 surface W atoms per square nanometre were obtained. The effect of the dopants on the isomerization activity of resultant catalysts was observed to occur through various possible mechanisms: e.g., changes in the structure of zirconia, i.e., by the formation of an active layer on the perturbed and/or unperturbed supporting framework on which the formation of WOx species occurs; through variations in the individual crystal phases in these supporting frameworks; and through variations in the surface properties including the surface area, acidity, etc. As shown by the results, the use of the metal-dopant ions strongly influenced the ratio of the ZrO2 crystallographic phases and thus the surface area of the final Pt/WO3-ZrO2 catalysts (i.e., the greater the proportion of tetragonal phase compared to the monoclinic phase, the greater the resulting surface area obtained), as well as the speciation of the WOx species of the final catalysts. In comparison, the acidity was modified to only a small extent. Accordingly, the effects connected with the metal-doping of ZrO2 could be summarized as follows: (a) The metal-doping increased the surface area of the support and thus changed the surface coverage of the WOx species on the ZrO2 support, i.e., the crucial parameter controlling the Pt/WO3-ZrO2 catalyst performance in paraffin isomerization. (b) This was also clearly manifested in the changes in reducibility of WO3-ZrO2, and formation of various WOx species and their distribution. Consequently, the metal-dopant ions dramatically influenced the resulting catalytic activity: the yield of iso-heptanes in the isomerization of n-heptane was increased substantially over the doped catalysts. Additionally, the doped catalysts exhibited considerable improvement in selectivity for isomers and the formation of low-molecular products was also minimized. Since the presence of dopant ions in the support framework increased the surface area of the support, the surface coverage by WOx species decreased accordingly. However, introduction of WOx onto a pure ZrO2 support, even without any dopant, also led to an increased surface area compared to that of pure ZrO2 without WOx. The final surface area of metal-doped and WOx-impregnated samples after high-temperature calcination and their resulting surface coverage by WOx species varied in the range of 7.0–13.70W/nm2 (compared to a value of 6.10W/nm2 for an undoped ZrO2 surface)). Thus, it is not clear whether the resulting activity is determined principally by this coverage parameter or whether it is also influenced by the other parameters. These results suggest that WOx surface coverage is the key parameter determining catalyst performance, as illustrated by the data summarized in Table 5 and Fig. 5 Fig. 6 . The variability of WOx-coverage (due to changes in the ZrO2 area induced by metal-doping) in the studied samples (in the range 6.1–13.7W/nm2) is thus directly reflected in the activity of the resultant Pt/WO3-ZrO2, and the corresponding yield of iso-heptanes was between 41 and 59% (Fig. 6). An inverse, linear correlation was found between the acidity and Pt/WO3-ZrO2 activity (Fig. 7 ), possibly due to the role of the acid sites in the side reactions of cracking, which would be detrimental for the isomerization reaction. Thus, it is apparent that the isomerization activity is primarily controlled by changes in the WOx surface density over the ZrO2, which is in agreement with previously reported results [32,34–36] concerning the variability in WOx/ZrO2 surface density; where such variability was achieved by modification of the pre-calcination conditions of the parent ZrO2 used for catalyst preparation [37]. 5 Conclusions The use of metal ion dopants, i.e., Al, Si and Fe-metal ions, influenced the zirconia surface, acidity and WOx nuclearity as well as the red/ox properties of WO3-ZrO2. The addition of dopants enhanced the Pt/WO3-ZrO2 isomerization activity at reaction temperatures over 250°C. For all studied catalysts, doped and undoped, the key parameter was demonstrated to be the surface coverage by WOx species. The acidity, reducibility and nuclearity of the WOx layer were also changed by the dopants but were not directly reflected in the resulting catalyst activity. coredata.dc:description: Selected Pt/WO3-ZrO2 catalysts, promoted by Al, Si and Fe metal ions and isomorphously substituted into the zirconia framework, were studied and compared with their undoped equivalents as catalysts for C7 isomerization. They were characterized by XRD, UV–vis and TPD-TPR techniques. A mechanism was proposed for the positive dopant effect on the catalyst activity.
coredata.dc:title: Impact of dopant metal ions in the framework of parent zirconia on the n-heptane isomerization activity of the Pt/WO3-ZrO2 catalysts
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
